title: There’s something about Sunbury: Melbourne suburb on global list
text:
Humble old town turned global hot spot Sunbury’s crown as one of the world’s fastest-growing locations for Airbnbs is making waves.

It’s understood an international investor recently snapped up a property in the outer northwestern Melbourne suburb with a view to listing it on the short-stay website.

Sunbury’s 356 per cent Airbnb year-on-year booking increase between 2018 and 2019 ranked fourth worldwide, topping Tokyo (17), Vanuatu (10), Luxembourg (8) and Romania (5).

RELATED: Melbourne Airbnbs: short-stay rentals growing in family suburbs

Sunbury ranked among top growth cities for Airbnb bookings

Mt Martha, Wollert, Sunbury among suburbs bucking the trend as Melbourne market falls

But the real estate market is still dominated by owner-occupiers, with first-home buyers driving the action and not having to do battle with worldwide players — yet.

Leading Real Estate director Adam Sacco said Sunbury was a “satellite city” to Melbourne that was only about 25-30 minutes drive to and from the CBD.

“And you are one of the closest for affordability in regards to the airport as well,” he said.

“It definitely does have appeal and there aren’t really hotels or accommodation here to cater for that and Sunbury’s got a few wedding venues as well — it does make sense.”

Mr Sacco said it was “only a matter of time” before hotel operators looked to build as well.

“It’s so central to everything and it’s fully sustainable in its own right.

“There’s the movies, shopping complexes, there’s a new one at the Rosenthal housing estate that cost $17.8 million with a new Woolworths; there are five new estates opening in Sunbury all with signs saying land sales will be opening soon.

“The population of Sunbury is about 42,000 and it’s estimated to grow to 60,000 by 2023.”

It could be a good time to get into the local market, as well: Sunbury’s median house price was stagnant at $535,000 in the year to July, after a 40 per cent boost in the past three years and 48.6 per cent over five.

Milwaukee, Bilbao, and Buriram in Thailand were the top three cities worldwide in Airbnb’s 20 trending destinations for 2020, based on year-over-year growth in bookings.

“A short drive northwest of Melbourne, the suburb of Sunbury is a popular spot with savvy locals thanks to its wildlife, wineries and Victorian-era architecture,” the Airbnb page states.

“Its biggest claim to fame is as the birthplace of cricket’s most sought-after trophy — The Ashes. In 2020, Sunbury looks to attract cricket fans from near and far as Melbourne will be hosting the ICC T20 World Cup.”

Woodend Old School House now a picturesque bed and breakfast

scott.carbines@news.com.au
description: Humble old town turned global hot spot Sunbury’s crown as one of the world’s fastest-growing locations for Airbnbs is making waves, but are they breaking in the real estate market yet?
